subject: Re: [junit] Can I test web application using JUnit?
msgSnippet: ... Cactus makes for prettier tests. If you have no desire nor permission to refactor the servlet under test, it is a good choice, but mostly for testing JSP
messageBody:
Jason Rogers wrote:

> On Mon, 2003-09-22 at 05:35, Narendra S wrote:
> > If u are interested in testing the servlets try Cactus
> > http://jakarta.apache.org/cactus/index.html
> > ----- Original Message -----
>
> I would suggest qualifying that statement. I have been a part of 5
> large projects now that have all used the Servlet technology. Not a
> single one of those projects needed the overhead of Cactus. In fact, I
> am not sure what the benefit of it is. (That is not a derogatory
> remark.) Can you sum up the things that Cactus brings to the table over
> JUnit+HTTPUnit or JUnit+HTMLUnit?

Cactus makes for prettier tests. If you have no desire nor permission to
refactor the servlet under test, it is a good choice, but mostly for
testing JSP tag handlers and so on; not so much for servlets.

To test web application from end to end, use HTMLUnit.

To test servlets as objects, use ServletUnit (part of HTTPUnit).

Of course, if one simply codes 99.99% of one's app outside the servlet
as one should, then use JUnit.
